text: Lets you draw shapes and fill them with scattered assets.
This node is designed to customize the behavior of the
The kind of shape you draw in the viewer. When you finish drawing a shape, the brush fills it with assets, using the parameters on the
Click to place one corner of a rectangle, then drag to or click to place the adjacent corner, then click to place the opposite corner.
Press to place the center of a circle, and drag out to define the circle’s radius.
Drag to draw the outline of a freeform shape.
When this is on, snap assets to the intersected surface using the
Sets the up direction of assets created to fill the
This is a scale on the density set below.
How to control the density of the scattered instances.
Randomly scatter a fixed number of points inside the fill shape.
The parameters on this tab control attributes on the points that specify how to scale and orient the objects that will be copied/instanced onto the points, such as with

The best way to use these parameters is to set up your copying/instancing network to copy the objects onto the points, then select this node and tweak the parameters, so you can see how they affect the copied/instanced objects.
By default, Houdini expects instance geometry to be modeled so that the
direction (for example, from the root of a tree to the top) is along the +Y axis, and the
direction (for example, from the back of a car to the front) is along the +Z axis. You can modify this using the parameters in the
The axis of the instanced objects to map onto the surface normal direction. The default is
Maps the initial X direction to the oriented normals.
Maps the initial Y direction to the oriented normals.
Maps the initial Z direction to the oriented normals.
Maps the direction specified by the
, the node will map this custom vector to the surface normal at each point.
The axis of the instanced objects to map onto the
below. This controls how the instanced geometry rotates around the surface normal direction.
Aligns the X direction with the
Aligns the Y direction with the
Aligns the Z direction with the
Aligns the custom vector specified by
, this is the direction to align with the
This is the direction that the
will be pointed in after mapping the
with the custom direction specified by the
on each point individually with the direction specified by the point attribute
, this defines the direction that the
, this is the name of a vector attribute on the surface that controls the forward direction at each point.
is on, the node will blend the
direction of the instances by a certain amount away from the surface normal direction toward the
direction of the instances away from the surface normal direction toward this direction.
For example, if all instances are pointing
away from the surface, and you set this to
instead of away from the surface.
Blends normals toward the X direction.
Blends normals toward the Y direction.
Blends normals toward the Z direction.
Blends normals toward the custom direction specified by the
Blends normals toward the direction specified on each point by the
, this is the direction to blend the point normals toward.
, this is the name of an attribute containing the direction vector to blend the point normals toward.
The amount to blend the point normal direction with the target direction.
just uses the target direction. Values in between blend between the point normals and the target direction.
by an attribute on the input geometry.
The name of an attribute on the surface to use to scale the blending
Randomly rotated away from default up direction by up to 30 degrees.
Rotates each instance away from the default
direction by a certain amount, up to this maximum number of degrees. This creates variation in the orientation of the instances.
If you set the popup menu next to
, you can scale the maximum random angle change using an attribute on the surface.
When the popup menu next to
, this is the name of an attribute on the surface to use to scale the
The following parameters control how the node rotates the instances around the
The minimum angle to be generated randomly.
The maximum angle to be generated randomly.
Whether to round the sampled random angle to the closest integer multiple of

The value to round the sampled random angle to the closest integer multiple of. For example, if you are instancing buildings, you can rotate them but keep them aligned by only allowing them to rotate 90 degrees at a time.
This is the offset angle to rotate each point around its normal vector after the random part of the rotation has been determined.
on each point by an attribute.
An attribute specifying the factor to scale the
Whether to use a ramp to define the inverse CDF of the probability distribution that random angles are sampled from.
A ramp defining the inverse CDF of the probability distribution that random angles are sampled from between the
This tab is not available when
Add Attributes to Existing Point Cloud
Whether to add noise to the scattered point positions
influencing points to be near the constraint points.
is on, this controls the influence falloff for each successive noise layer.
is on, this is the maximum displacement added to the points by the noise.
is on, this is the base feature size of the generated noise.
The node scatters the new points, then iteratively moves the points to satisfy spacing and other constraints. This iterative process is called
The number of relax iterations to apply to the points. More iterations are slower but can give better positioning of the points.
Whether to remove points that are too close to one another to preserve spacing constraints.
Scattering around constraint points with avoid constraint points but without remove overlapping points.
Scattering around constraint points with avoid constraint points and remove overlapping points.
The minimum amount of overlap allowed, as a fraction of the radius required for a point to be removed.
When this is on, you can specify additional constraint points from the second input in the
below. The scattered points will be pulled toward or pushed away from these constraint points during relaxation, based on each constraint point’s
Scattering around constraint points without avoid constraint points or remove overlapping points.
Scattering around constraint points with avoid constraint points and remove overlapping points.
is on, this is the group of points in the second input that repel or attract the scattered points. The
attribute on each constraint point controls how strongly the point repels the scattered points (if
is negative). Leave this blank to use all existing points in the second input. To select points by the
attribute on the points in the
Turn on the checkbox next to
to prevent the node from creating more than a certain maximum number of points.

The maximum number of points this node is allowed to generate. If you accidentally set some combination of parameters that causes a huge spike in point density, this can prevent the node from cooking for an extremely long time, or running out of memory. This is especially useful in batch processing where a human is not available to press
Turn this checkbox on to create an attribute on the scattered points containing the primitive number of the corresponding primitive (polygon face) on the surface.
The name of an attribute to create on the scattered points containing the primitive number of the corresponding primitive (polygon face) on the surface.
Turn this checkbox on to create an attribute on the scattered points containing the corresponding UVW coordinates on the surface.
The name of an attribute to create on the scattered points containing the corresponding UVW coordinates on the surface.
Turn this checkbox on to create an attribute on the scattered points containing the radius of the point (this will affect the object size when you copy/instance onto the points).
The name of an attribute to create on the scattered points containing the point radius (this will affect the object size when you copy/instance onto the points). This is on by default with the name
(this is Houdini’s standard instancing attribute for point scale).
Turn this checkbox on to create an attribute on the scattered points containing the orientation matrix of the point (this will affect the object orientation when you copy/instance onto the points).

The name of an attribute to create on the scattered points containing the orientation matrix of the point (this will affect the object orientation when you copy/instance onto the points). This is on by default with the name
(this is one of Houdini’s standard instancing attributes for orientation).
A space-separated list of point attributes to copy from the surface onto the scattered points. For example, if the surface has point colors, you can specify
to transfer the surface color onto the scattered points. The default is
A space-separated list of vertex attributes to copy from the surface onto the scattered points. The default is
A space-separated list of primitive (polygon face) attributes to copy from the surface onto the scattered points. The default is empty, meaning transfer
A space-separated list of detail (whole geometry) attributes to copy from the surface onto the scattered points. The default is empty, meaning transfer
patterns will be copied from the surface onto the scattered points.
Apply this scale to every instanced asset. This can be useful when the assets were modelled at a different scale than the scene you are scattering them into.
How the brush picks the assets to instance onto the filled points.
Cycle through the working set assets while iterating over each scattered point. This results in a more even distribution of all the assets in the working set than
Break the fill shape into random cellular patches (using a Worley noise function) and fill each patch with the same asset.
Assign assets to points based on the pattern generated by a noise function.
Pick a random asset from the working set to instance onto each point.
Assign assets to points based on the result of one or more VEX expressions.
Randomly re-assign which assets are assigned to the different points/patches. If
, this will appear to simply re-randomize the points. When
, this will keep the patches/patterns created by the mode, but randomize which asset goes with each patch/pattern. Note that you can use
is on, the random number seed to use for shuffling. Changing this number will give a different
outcome. For example, if you want different orderings in each frame, set the seed to
(above), but instead of re-assigning assets randomly, it shifts each asset to the next one in order in the working set. (Note that you can use this and

shuffle and offset the asset choices.) This can be useful if the order of your working set has meaning (for example, if it goes from big assets to small assets), or if you just want to try some different outcomes to see how they look.
Controls the average size of the patches.
Allows you to control the average height, width, and depth of the patches separately.
Moves the noise field relative to the points.
These parameters can optionally add distortion on top of the base noise pattern.
The strength of distortion to add.
An offset added to the center of the distortion map.
The function to use to generate the noise field. The node uses the point positions as the seed for the random number generator.
Controls the size of the noise features.
Allows you to control the height, width, and depth of the noise features separately.
Moves the noise field relative to the points.
The number of combined noise layers.
The influence falloff for each successive noise layer.
These parameters can optionally add distortion on top of the base noise pattern.
Widens the peaks or valleys of the noise output.
A ramp used to remap noise values.
The way of specifying the weight that each piece is given.
Give each piece a weighting using a multiparm, allowing you to make some pieces more likely than others.
If you choose this option, click the
button to automatically set up the multiparm based on the pieces in the second input.
Use a primitive float attribute on the piece geometry that sets the piece’s random weighting. The weighting for a piece is the
of this attribute’s values across the primitives of the piece.
, this is the seed value for the random number generator that chooses between weighted alternatives.
, click this button to automatically set up the multiparm based on the pieces in the second input.
A button that will automatically fill out the

parameters
        such that each unique piece in the geometry is included in the list.
The number of pieces to specify weights for in the multiparm.
The attribute value for this piece.
A value representing how likely this piece is to appear in the chain, relative to other pieces. The weights of all pieces are normalized to add up to
and then used as probabilities. For example, if three pieces have weights of
, the last piece is likely to appear 50% of the time, while the other two are each likely to appear 25% of the time.
, the name of a primitive float attribute on the piece geometry that sets the piece’s random weighting. The weighting for a piece is the
of this attribute’s values across the primitives of the piece.
The number of VEX expressions to test.
Use the checkbox next to each expression to control whether it is used or not.
The name of the piece to assign to points where the expression returns true. If you enter a space-separated list of piece names, the node will choose one randomly.
The VEX expression to run for each point. If the expression evaluates to a non-zero value, it
the point and the corresponding piece will be assigned to the point.
When none of the rules in the multiparm match, use this piece. If you enter a space-separated list of piece names, the node will choose one randomly.
Turn on the checkbox next to
to create a group in the output containing any unmatched points.
Turn on the checkbox and enter a group name to create a group in the output containing any unmatched points.
The seed value for the random number generator for when the node chooses between alternatives.

title: Fill (layout brush)
summary: Lets you draw shapes and fill them with scattered assets.
